required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasonic Cavitation on Abdominal Obesity in Adolescent Females
clinical_study.official_title: Ultrasonic Cavitation on Abdominal Obesity in Adolescent Females

collaborator.agency: Ghada ebrahim El Refaye - Department of Physical Therapy for Women's Health, Faculty of Physical Therapy, Cairo University, Egypt

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of ultrasonic cavitation on abdominal obesity in females. Fifty volunteer females with abdominal obesity participated in the study.

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this study was to determine the effectiveness of ultrasonic cavitation on abdominal obesity in adolescent females. Fifty volunteer females with abdominal obesity participated in the study.
Group (A) consisted of 25 females who treated by ultrasonic cavitation on abdominal region for 30 minutes and aerobic exercises for 30 minutes, 2 times per week for 6 weeks ; group (B) consisted of 25 females who performed aerobic exercise and low caloric diet.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Group (A) consisted of 25 females who treated by ultrasonic cavitation, group (B) consisted of 25 females who performed aerobic exercise.

primary_outcome.description: was used to estimate body composition, in particular body fat and muscle mass, where a weak electric current flows through the body and the voltage is measured in order to calculate impedance (resistance) of the body. Most body water is stored in muscle in both groups A and B

secondary_outcome.description: was used to measure the waist circumference and amount of subcutaneous fat when the fold for all females in both groups (A&B)

arm_group.description: ultrasonic cavitation applied on abdominal region for 30 minutes, 2 times per week for 6 weeks.
aerobic exercises through treadmill (60-70% of VO2 max.) for 30 minutes, 2 times per week for 6 weeks

intervention.description: A low-calorie diet is a structured eating plan that restricts daily caloric intake, commonly for weight loss. Following a low-calorie diet typically means consuming around 1,200 to 1,500 calories per day, which creates a calorie deficit that can lead to weight loss. A low-calorie diet can be effective, but it requires a lot of discipline to work and be safe.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Their ages were range from 17 to 21 years old.
- Their body mass index less than 35kg/m2.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Females with BMI exceed 35kg/m2.
- Females have psychological disorders.
- cardiac diseases.
- hypertension

facility.name: Faculty of physical therapy- Cairo University

responsible_party.investigator_title: assistant professor Department of Physical Therapy for Women's Health, Faculty of Physical therapy, Cairo University, Egypt
